newsitem.title: GREECE: PRESS DIGEST - GREEK FINANCIAL NEWS- AUG 19.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - GREEK FINANCIAL NEWS- AUG 19.

text.p: Leading stories in the Greek financial press:

-- The finance ministry's move to cut by 10 basis points the rate on the 12-month T-bills to be offered to the public on Wednesday is largely seen as a signal to lower interest rates, in accordance with the Bank of Greece's recent 30 basis point cut in its basic depo facility rate to 11.3 percent.

-- Top officials from the ministries of finance and national economy will meet today to discuss the means to boost fiscal revenue growth over the coming two months, bringing it in line with the 1997 Budget's full year target.

-- The large share capital increase of National Bank, around 100 billion drachmas, is expected to take place in the latter half of October 1997. The case for a public subscription for National's new shares has been ruled out.

-- The 1998 Budget of OTE Telecom anticipates revenue growth of 16 percent to 975 billion drachmas from an estimated 840 billion in 1997, with revenue per employee growth targeted at 17 percent. According to provisional data, OTE's pretax profit in the first half of 1997 has grown in excess of 30 percent relative to the respective period of 1996, on turnover growth of 25 percent.

-- A senior national economy ministry official has told the newspaper that a depreciation of the drachma in 1997 would set the government's stabilisation policy off course and would cause a large shortfall from inflation targets.
-- The set of objective prices used in the calculation of taxation on real estate transactions will be revised upwards in September 1997 and will come in effect in 1998.
-- Development ministry officials contemplate a shift in development policy away from subsidies towards the introduction of substantial tax incentives.

-- Proposals for supplies and contracts submitted by state entities to the development ministry by end-July, excluding OTE Telecom and the Public Power Corporation (DEH), were valued at 450 billion drachmas. The total value of these supplies and contracts is expected to increase substantially before the end-1997 deadline.

-- The Thessaloniki branch of the Athens stock exchange will seek the transfer of the Athens bourse's small-cap Parallel market to Thessaloniki as part of its effort to upgrade its role in the Greek capital market and attrack listings from northern Greece and the Balkan countries. --Angelos Kiosklis, Athens Newsroom +301 3311812-4
